climbs.name: High and Wild
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Max Fisher and Mike Delaney

content.description:
Nice long easy route with a short crux ice pitch near the top. The final 100 feet of ice can have wild some wild formations.

There are two variations to the final 60 meters of this climb:

High and Wild right WI3 M3 55m FA Max Fisher Luc G 

High and Wild left WI4 25m FA Luc Gallant & Max Fisher.

Just left of Maritime Alpinism. Start on an easy rock then ice ramp leading to a long low angled ice flow. 
A rack of screws. Screw and tree anchors.

The gem of the area. Long, intricate line that leads to a wonderfully steep pitch of ice on a big headwall. 

This is the first line encountered in the area. It is quite easy to see from the beach. 
A rack of screws. Screw anchors for all belays except tree anchor on the top.

climbs.name: Maritime Alpinism
climbs.fa: Max Fisher and Greg Hughes December 2015

content.description:
After the long first pitch follow the narrow gully up and right of a snow field. The gully eventually leads to a short headwall finish.

Immediately left of Living in the Spirit Of. Start as close as you can to a hanging curtain of ice. It is not likely the curtain will ever touch down as it is undercut by the tides. Start up on ice and rock to hit the left side of the curtain. Follow this to a lower angled snow and ice field that leads to the narrow gulley and then the headwall. 
A rack of screws. Screw and tree anchors.

climbs.name: Snuff Film
climbs.fa: Matt MacPhee and Matthew Peck December 2017

content.description:
A miss-adventure. While attempting High and wild, the FA team found both exits to be in terrible condition due to a thaw. While attempting to access the right access, Matt MacPhee became committed to a mixed rock pitch and made the choice to succeed upwards. Excellent mental control allowed the dispatch of the pitch with almost no protection. 5.8 ish climbing on choss from the scree slope at the top of p3 of H&W. gain a ledge 3m from the scree and trend up and right towards a small birch tree on a ledge to belay. 

Pitch two heads up a ramp to the left, through alders and up a decomposing slope to a more substantial birch. 

A final muddy gap will see the exit.


Located between Maritime Alpinism and High and Wild.
A rack of screws and pixie dust. Tree/screw anchors.
Some of the longest, most aesthetic routes are found in this area.
